chapter.title: Troubleshooting
chapter.para: This chapter covers common problems and their solutions.

section.title: Object not found in heap
section.programlisting: org.forgerock.json.fluent.JsonValueException: /handler: object Router2 not found in heap at org.forgerock.openig.heap.HeapUtil.getRequiredObject(HeapUtil.java:69) at org.forgerock.openig.servlet.GatewayServlet.init(GatewayServlet.java:188) at org.eclipse.jetty.servlet.ServletHolder.initServlet(ServletHolder.java:595)
section.para: You have specified "handler": "Router2" in config.json, but no handler configuration object named "Router2" exists. Make sure you have added an entry for the handler and that you have correctly spelled its name.

section.title: ${projectName} ignores a configuration field
section.para: ${projectName} ignores the configuration, and nothing appears in debug log output.
If you are more lucky, this can also manifest itself by an error such as the following.
section.programlisting: Caused by: org.forgerock.json.fluent.JsonValueException: /heap/objects/2/config/handler: Expecting a value at org.forgerock.json.fluent.JsonValue.required(JsonValue.java:1398) at org.forgerock.openig.heap.HeapUtil.getRequiredObject(HeapUtil.java:67) at org.forgerock.openig.filter.Chain$Heaplet.create(Chain.java:102) at org.forgerock.openig.heap.GenericHeaplet.create(GenericHeaplet.java:83) at org.forgerock.openig.heap.HeapImpl.get(HeapImpl.java:107) at org.forgerock.openig.heap.HeapUtil.getRequiredObject(HeapUtil.java:67) ...
section.para: When ${projectName} does not recognize an argument name, it ignores the argument. This is both a feature and a limitation of the JSON format.

This is a feature because it allows you to add comments by using the field name "comment", or to comment out a field using a single character, as in "_captureEntity": true rather than "captureEntity": true.
This is a limitation because spelling errors in field names for optional settings cause ${projectName} to silently ignore the field.

section.title: Unexpected character (x) at position 1103
section.programlisting:
HTTP ERROR 500 Problem accessing /. Reason:
Unexpected character (x) at position 1103
section.para: This error usually means a missing double quote or a missing bracket in the configuration file. Use a JSON editor or JSON validation tool such as JSONLint to make sure your JSON is valid.

section.title: The values in the flat file are incorrect
section.para: Ensure the flat file is readable by the user running the container for ${projectName}. Values are all characters, including space and tabs, between the separator, so make sure the values are not padded with spaces.

section.title: Problem accessing URL
section.programlisting:
HTTP ERROR 500
Problem accessing /myURL . Reason:
java.lang.String cannot be cast to java.util.List Caused by: java.lang.ClassCastException: java.lang.String cannot be cast to java.util.List at org.forgerock.openig.filter.LoggingFilter.writeHeaders(LoggingFilter.java:132 at org.forgerock.openig.filter.LoggingFilter.logResponse(LoggingFilter.java:119) at org.forgerock.openig.filter.LoggingFilter.filter(LoggingFilter.java:86) at org.forgerock.openig.filter.Chain.handle(Chain.java:54)
section.para: This error is typically encountered when using the AssignmentFilter and setting a string value for one of the Headers. All headers are stored in Lists so the header must be addressed with a subscript.

For example, if you try to set exchange.request.headers['Location'] for a redirect in the response object, you should instead set exchange.request.headers['Location'][0]. A header without a subscript leads to the error above.

section.title: ${projectName} is not logging users in
section.para: If you are proxying to more than one application in multiple DNS domains, you must make sure your container is enabled for domain cookies. For details on your specific container, see the section on Configuring Deployment Containers.

section.title: Read timed out error when sending a request
section.para: If a "baseURI" configuration setting causes a request to come back to ${projectName}, ${projectName} never produces a response to the request. You then observe the following behavior.

You send a request and ${projectName} seems to hang. Then you see a failure message, HTTP Status 500 - Read timed out, accompanied by ${projectName} throwing an exception, java.net.SocketTimeoutException: Read timed out.
To fix this issue, make sure that "baseURI" configuration settings do not cause requests to come back to ${projectName}.

section.title: ${projectName} does not use new route configuration
section.para: ${projectName} loads all configuration at startup. By default, it then periodically reloads changed route configurations.
If you make changes to a route that result in an invalid configuration, ${projectName} logs errors, but it keeps the previous, correct configuration, and continues to use the old route.
${projectName} only uses the new configuration after you save a valid version or when you restart ${projectName}.

Of course, if you restart ${projectName} with an invalid route configuration, then ${projectName} tries to load the invalid route at startup and logs an error. In that case, if there is no default handler to accept any incoming exchange for the invalid route, then you see an error, No handler to dispatch to.

section.title: Make ${projectName} skip a route
section.para: If you have copied routes from another ${projectName} server, those routes might depend on environment or container configuration that you have not yet configured locally.
You can work around this problem by changing the route file extension. A router ignores route files that do not have the .json extension.

For example, suppose you copy route all sample route configurations from the documentation, and then start ${projectName} without first configuring your container. This can result in an error such as the following.

informalexample.programlisting: org.forgerock.json.fluent.JsonValueException: /heap/objects/1/config/dataSource: javax.naming.NameNotFoundException; remaining name 'jdbc/forgerock' at org.forgerock.openig.filter.SqlAttributesFilter$Heaplet.create(SqlAttributesFilter.java:175) at org.forgerock.openig.heap.GenericHeaplet.create(GenericHeaplet.java:80) at org.forgerock.openig.heap.HeapImpl.get(HeapImpl.java:107) at org.forgerock.openig.heap.HeapImpl.init(HeapImpl.java:97) at org.forgerock.openig.handler.router.RouteBuilder.createHeap(RouteBuilder.java:105) at org.forgerock.openig.handler.router.RouteBuilder.build(RouteBuilder.java:66) at org.forgerock.openig.handler.router.RouterHandler.onAddedFile(RouterHandler.java:197) at org.forgerock.openig.handler.router.RouterHandler.onChanges(RouterHandler.java:179) at org.forgerock.openig.handler.router.DirectoryMonitor.scan(DirectoryMonitor.java:138)

section.para: This arises from the route in 03-sql.json, which defines an "SqlAttributesFilter" that depends on a JNDI data source configured in the container.
To prevent ${projectName} from loading the route configuration until you have had time to configure the container, change the file extension to render the route inactive.
If necessary, restart the container to force ${projectName} to reload the configuration.
When you have configured the data source in the container, change the file extension back to .json to render the route active again.
